subject: Re: A Growing Problem
msgSnippet: Hi Parag, ... Consider extracting the repeated code into a separate method, somehing like this: private void checkCreate_Label(String date, String lot, String
messageBody:
Hi Parag,

> You might work around this limitation by placing all test cases and
> assert statements sequentially inside a single method. This
> approachsuffers from two limitations. The first limitation is the
> need to replicate the test code for every test case. Even if you
> have only two or three lines of code per test case, the size of the
> method will mushroom and become hard to maintain (and read). See
> example below

Consider extracting the repeated code into a separate method, somehing
like this:


private void checkCreate_Label(String date, String lot,

String parm3, String expectedLabel)
{
try {
BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(date, lot, parm3);
assert ( aBatchLabel.getBatchLabel().equals(expectedLabel)) ;
} catch (Exception e) {
assert ( "Exception:" + e, false );
}
}

private void checkCreate_Exception(String date, String lot,
String parm3,
Class expectedException)
{
try {
BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(date, lot, parm3);
} catch (Exception e) {
assert("Wrong Exception thrown: " + e,
e.getClass().equals(expectedException)) ;
}
}

public void testCreateBatchLabelNoInnerClass()
{
checkCreate_Label("20010530", "A13", "1", "A13-1 EXP. 05/01");
checkCreate_Label("20010530", "A13", "", "A13 EXP. 05/01");
checkCreate_Label("20011231", "A13", "1", "A13-1 EXP. 12/01");
checkCreate_Label("20010101", "A13", "1", "A13-1 EXP. 01/01");
checkCreate_Label("20010101", "A123", "99", "A123-99 EXP. 01/01");

checkCreate_Exception("2001530", "A999", "", BadDateException.class);
checkCreate_Exception("20010530", "913", "1", BadLotException.class);

// etc

}

I've just done that for a bunch of my own tests. The one drawback is
that I have to scan more the stack trace to identify the actual test,
but so far I haven't found that to be a problem.

Dale
